author: {'steamid': '76561197966913375', 'num_games_owned': 1010, 'num_reviews': 192, 'playtime_forever': 683, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 683, 'last_played': 1499275840}
review:
The campaign serves as a tutorial, followed by a series of increasingly unfair scenarios, involving more victory conditions for you and/or better starting conditions for the opponent. For skirmish games against the AI or online play (featuring both real-time and asynchronous games), only a handful of map layouts are available, but specific business locations are randomized for more replay value. The goal is to earn a specific number of victory points, earned by blackmailing churches, bribing guilds (both of which simply involve having the maximum number of units inside), or assassinating neutral characters (plus other alternative methods depending on the map). There are two resources in the game: gold, earned from buildings and burglary, is used to purchase units, while lanterns (from different buildings) are used to purchase technology upgrades. Units include the master thief, used to scout and burgle houses, the urchin to infiltrate businesses, the thug to block paths, the gang to attack enemies, the saboteur to plant traps on buildings, the assassin to instantly kill any unit, and the truant officer to evict all urchins in an enemy building. There are multiple strategies you can employ towards victory, and ways to counter each plan as well. The AI is generally a good player (which makes the concessions it's granted in the campaign unnecessary), choosing a varied strategy each game. Antihero is an approachable turn-based strategy game with a unique setting and compelling gameplay mechanics.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vzcYI0_gfWU

author: {'steamid': '76561198005720127', 'num_games_owned': 749, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 1201, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 648, 'last_played': 1704570858}
review:
An interesting turn-based digital board game with a really nice aesthetic. You play as a leader of a thieves' guild, hiring street urchins, gangs and thugs, and even assassins to explore, burgle and take over the Victorian themed city.

Pros:
+Campaign - although not very long there is a story-driven campaign to help you learn the game. The story is not particularly ground breaking but the various scenarios you face on each map provide interesting venues to explore your strategies. On one map part of your victory conditions is to eliminate three gangs a la Gangs of New York. On another you will be trying to infiltrate and protect a ship carrying precious cargo, in order to have your urchins carry the goods back to your hideout.
+AI - the AI seems to be pretty decent, pursuing victory conditions and trying to double cross you whenever possible. You need to play efficiently and agressively pursue the victory conditions yourself if you want to stand a chance.
+Local and Online Multiplayer - you can play against humain opponents both online and via Hot Seat, with customizable rulesets.
Replayability - while the maps seem to be premade layouts the districts containing building are randomized each game. This means even if you are playing the same map twice you will find buildings and enemies in different places each time (this includes the campaign missions). THere are also 3 upgrade trees, allowing for different approach.
Aesthetics - the map and characters are nicely drawn and animated. There are clear inspirations from other media, like the criminal gang being lead by a character resembling Daniel Day-Lewis' from Gangs of New York, or the assassin looking similar to Evie Frye from Assasin's Creed: Syndicate.

Neutral:
+/-Music - the soundtrack fits the setting and does an OK jub, but is otherwise unremarkable. I expect most people would get bored by it sonner than later and would switch to something else.
+/-Game modes - currently it seems the only game mode is 1v1. It is designed very well for this mode and it's difficult to say whether other ones would be equally enjoyable. If you are however looking for a game with groups of friends there is currently no mode for that.

Cons:
-UI While mostly clear and understandable there are some minor issues. Since the map is being viewed in an isometric view, including the characters I've had several moments where it was difficult to select the character/building I wanted to interact with. I would also appreciate it if it showed what the effects of interacting with buildings are while hovering over them. Some of the icons are also a bit larger than necessary.

Summary: A pretty solid board game that is fun in its current state, with some minor issues that could get ironed out and good base for future expansion. Definitely recommended if you are a fan of the genre.

author: {'steamid': '76561198002874170', 'num_games_owned': 5476, 'num_reviews': 160, 'playtime_forever': 1041, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 760, 'last_played': 1573533124}
review:
I LOVE THIS GAME!

Finally something fresh in my library that had it all. Tuned, easy to learn mechanics. This game is a multiplayer style board game. You run a thieves guild vs opponents and try to take board control using a number of interesting unlocks. 

The art style is similar to Don't Starve which I always loved that style.

The single player game is a lot of fun and there are serveral map variants in place to make the game not get repetitive (like freaking Armello..god. They could learn a thing or two from this developer).

So far I'm having a lot of fun and I've already gotten my value out of it. Pick it up if you want a fun, screw your friends, kind of board game experience.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995853347', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 69, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 69, 'last_played': 1499729185}
review:
Avant toute chose, je tiens à dire que je suis à une petite heure de jeu, que j'ai fini les trois premières missions de la campagne, et que j'ai fait une partie rapide en difficulté normale, que j'ai gagné 5 à 2.

Antihero est un petit jeu indépendant de gestion d'une guilde de voleur. Une nouveauté, probablement le premier jeu de ce type ! Le but est de prendre main sur une ville, alors qu'on a en face de nous un concurrent. Pour cela, différents types de persos, qui ont tous un coût. Chaque perso aura son utilité, que ce soit pour prendre contrôle d'un bâtiment, pour mettre des pièges, pour attaquer les autres, etc.. Le jeu se joue au tour par tour, il y a également un arbre de compétences pour débloquer les différents persos et compétences ! 

Pour gagner, il faut réaliser certaines missions, tuer un certain personnage, garder le contrôle d'un endroit en particulier, et le premier à atteindre le nombre nécessaire l'emporte. Du coup, on a un jeu de stratégie au tour par tour, qui fait aussi penser à un jeu de plateau ! 

Le jeu possède aussi un multi. De mon côté, je vois pas mal de potentiel. Pour l'instant, on ne peut faire que du 1VS1. Mais pourquoi pas avoir une plus grande Map, et avoir 4 guildes différentes qui s'affrontent ? Le jeu vient de sortir, et aura probablement des MAJ/DLC, le potentiel est clairement présent.

En mon heure de jeu, aucun bug à signaler, c'est fluide, mignon, aucun soucis !

Je vous laisse avec une vidéo découverte si vous voulez avoir plus d'infos ! :) 

https://youtu.be/yYY3T1D6aPI

Sur ce, je m'y remets !

author: {'steamid': '76561197990893828', 'num_games_owned': 2825, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 437, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 220, 'last_played': 1533321653}
review:
One of the types of game that is missing on Steam in a big way, is asynchronous multiplayer games. These are the games that you can play a turn, and then move on with your day, knowing that eventually your opponent will play theirs and you can come back to it later. 

Antihero is a perfect example of one of those kinds of games and it does a very good job of presenting a solid lobby system for matches. While the option exists to play a synchronous real time game as well, the asynchronousity is really where the game stands out. 

This is a solid strategy game, with enough options that you're planning out the future, but not enough to be overwhelming to strategy novices. A perfect entry game (if you're just starting into strategy), you'll be charmed by the well-done graphics, the theme, and the play. 

To put the finishing touch on the game, is a campaign that's long enough to show you how to do most  things, without sticking around too long and boring you. The game is designed as a multiplayer game, but you can tell that this campaign has been given a lot of love as well. 

If you want to just play the single player campaign, I'd say that there's still enough content at this price point to jump on the wagon. If you think you might dip your toe in the multiplayer scene as well, it's a no-brainer. Also, if you're looking for a multiplayer game with no toxicity, then this is it, because other than the actual gameplay, there is no interaction with the other people that you're playing with. 

Great game to chill out with... and the atmosphere is absolutely fantastic, held up by well-designed graphics, fantastic animations, and a sound effects board that goes with the game very well.

author: {'steamid': '76561197991948780', 'num_games_owned': 3193, 'num_reviews': 81, 'playtime_forever': 46693, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 153, 'playtime_at_review': 673, 'last_played': 1712451280}
review:
2017 game of the year for me. Don't let my low time played on STEAM mislead you, I have 100+ hours in addition to whatever steam says. Been playing this since First Access which I bought on itch.io earlier in the year, it’s so damn good. I cannot recall the last time I had so much fun playing a game. And with the turn based aspect offered in MP, I can fit games in around my busy work week. 

Single player campaign on HARD settings is a very good challenge (7 missions in so far), multiplayer is fantastic with a friendly and enthusiastic community. And just the right amount of stabbery and smack talk. 

Buy this, buy this for friends, and buy it for strangers. Just do it. There is no way someone cannot have fun playing this game. 

Anyone has any questions, hit me up.

author: {'steamid': '76561198019388720', 'num_games_owned': 670, 'num_reviews': 196, 'playtime_forever': 207, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 207, 'last_played': 1499657676}
review:
This is another unique board game video game like Carcassone, Catan, Ticket to Ride etc.

This game is just like those in that it's very unique and seems interesting and fairly well made. It's fun to play and it's always interesting learning a new game like these. This one is 1 vs 1 either in campaign, online or local hot-seat. I imagine playing against other human players would be quite fun. I do wish there was more than 1 vs 1 though, I would have liked this game as a 4 person game I think a bit more than 1 vs 1, but it is fun.

In this game the maps are all slightly different and affect the way you play with different win conditions. It's a neat idea.

One thing that I found to be questionable is possibly the A.I.

I have no idea why but I can't get past the 3rd campaign level, nor can I beat any skirmish games vs the computer. I am not sure if the A.I. player is extremely overpowered but they definitely seem to be. No matter what I do the computer player beats the crap out of me and counters every strategy I use. Nothing I do seems to work in my favor.

Either it's a way too difficult A.I. player or the game does not explain the how or why well enough in regards to what the player is supposed to be doing. I have no idea what I'm doing that's not working. Nothing I do seems to be good enough to defeat the computer player either on normal or easy. 

On top of that, the game has a "fog of war" type of thing. You have to scout certain areas in order to reveal whats under them. That's fine, except that all of your opponents moves are essentially hidden due to this, making it even harder to tell what I am doing wrong. I also am suspicious that the computer character was cheating in campaign level 3 but because I am not able to see what they are doing I can't confirm or deny, but it definitely feels that way.

Obviously these games are most fun when played against other humans and that's where I expect the most fun to come from with this title. Again though, it can be quite frustrating because it's very hard to tell what you are doing wrong when you lose and the fact that you can't really see what your opponent is doing makes you question the fairness of it all. Like I said before, I'm convinced that the computer player cheats in campaign level 3 but I don't know for certain because I can't see what they are doing most of the time.

Would I recommend this? I want to say yes, but I think I have to be more specific.

If you want this to play the campaign and skirmishes against the computer, I would have to say no.

If you want this to play specifically against other human players or your friends either online or local hot-set style, I would say yes - BUT - only after checking out some sort of tutorial videos. The game unfortunately does not train you well enough how to play it and can leave you very frustrated especially after a large losing streak where you have no idea what you did wrong in any of the games.

author: {'steamid': '76561198016131047', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 96, 'playtime_forever': 384, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 378, 'last_played': 1687295275}
review:
Really fun little game. I like how cartoony and simple it looks, but how in-depth and tactical it actually is. On the technical note; I have found no bugs or technical issues (on my setup atleast) so far. 

Usually these type of games are really easy and you'll figure out what is going on within an hour, but even on normal it offers a good challange. Some really quality animations and sounds aswell. I found the 1 - 2 cartoon page storyline amusing. 

Well worth to have turn based strategy game.
Kudo's for how well the tutorial was done.

author: {'steamid': '76561198036054895', 'num_games_owned': 236, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 793, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 499, 'last_played': 1500497708}
review:
Es un poco difícil de explicar por qué me enganchó de inmediato este juego, pero sepan que lo hizo. Hablando específicamente de la experiencia de un solo jugador.

Se trata de un juego de mesa digital en el que juegas como el líder una banda de ladrones que quieren conquistar la ciudad. Obviamente antes de que el ladrón rival lo haga. Para hacerlo debes tomar control de distintos edificios de la ciudad, utilizando varios tipos de unidades: desde huérfanos hasta gangs.

Pero como el líder de los ladrones, es tu deber hacer la exploración de los callejones, vecindarios y edificios de la ciudad y luego mandar ahí a tus unidades. Al mismo tiempo, debes ganar suficiente dinero para comprar unidades, y suficientes "lámparas" para comprar puntos de habilidad y volverte más fuerte. Cómo manejes tus recursos dictará mayormente si sales victorioso o no. Al mismo tiempo, debes tener cierta estrategia al adelantarte al enemigo, adivinar qué está haciendo y hacia donde va, y muy importante: no dejar que sus gangs se vuelvan más fuertes que las tuyas.

Todo esto situado en una Inglaterra Victoriana a la Charles Dickens con gran y peculiar arte y una atmósfera palpable. 

Además, resultó más difícil de lo que parecía en un principio, pues varias fases de la campaña tuve que repetirlas más de una vez porque me ganaban cruelmente. En total tomó unas 6 horas. Casi seguidas, porque no podía despegarme de él.

Eso sin contar que también cuenta con un modo multijugador. (Que no he probado, pero me resulta imposible pensar que será malo). 

Personalmente me parece un joyita que también es una ganga, por este precio. 

Actualizaré esto cuando también pruebe el modo multijugador. 

Por cierto, si les laten los juegos de mesa digital, Armello es también una gran opción.

author: {'steamid': '76561198006873223', 'num_games_owned': 3172, 'num_reviews': 180, 'playtime_forever': 735, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 735, 'last_played': 1501908009}
review:
Criado por Tim Conkling e publicado pela Versus Evil, Antihero é um jogo de tabuleiro digital em que você precisa ampliar sua rede criminosa numa cidade e expulsar a concorrência. Durante a era vitoriana, Diferente da temática fantástica vista em semelhante abordagem na série de livros Aventuras Fantásticas (A Cidade dos Ladrões / City of Thieves e Ladrão da Meia-noite / Midnight Rogue), este jogo se passa na era vitoriana e bebe da fonte de Charles Dickens e filmes como Gangues de Nova York.

A campanha dele é divertida, fácil de entender e de jogar, o alto nível de dificuldade e estratégia será no multiplayer onde diversos turnos precisam ser pensados a frente do seu oponente e um plano de vitória traçado com antecipação, algo que estamos vendo cada vez mais nos jogos de tabuleiro da atualidade devido a inspiração no estilo de design europeu. De uma certa forma, Antihero é uma estratégia 4X miniaturizada e longe de ser lento, pelo menos a princípio...

Antihero também possui multiplayer assíncrono e vale lembrar que as partidas regulares são 1x1 podendo demorar de 30-90 minutos dependendo da experiência dos jogadores (quando ambos jogadores estiverem jogando sem se ausentar).

Existem 4 formas de vencer:
1) Acumular suborno (bribe)
2) Acumular chantagem (blackmail)
3) Acumular vítimas (assassinate)
4) Roubar as jóias da coroa (em mapas específicos)

Qualquer combinação dos itens acima vai te levar a vitória, mas em algumas instâncias é preciso concluir certos objetivos para facilitar esse processo.

A mecânica de furtividade no tabuleiro é o que faz este jogo brilhar e que ao mesmo tempo quase impossibilita a existência de uma versão física dele. Não saber com precisão o que o oponente está tramando deixa tudo mais interessante e tenso, mas os jogadores mais ardilosos vão descobrir rápido as inteções do outro, seja através das habilidades das unidades diversas ou da árvore de progressão de cada guilda.

Pros:
- A interface de jogo é sucinta e bem explicativa.
- A música e efeitos sonoros são agradáveis (com vozes ocasionais na campanha) e encaixam bem com a temática.
- Modo confronto (skirmish) contra o computador.
- Seis unidades além do seu personagem e mecânicas de mesa variadas.
- A campanha não é muito longa, mas longa o bastante para um jogo de tabuleiro.
- Multiplayer assíncrono é algo raro em jogos e útil para os adoradores de xadrez, por exemplo.

Cons:

- A curva de aprendizado pode afastar os jogadores mais casuais, porém ela não é cruel.
- As partidas assíncronas podem permitir que os jogadores façam seus turnos num outro dia e horário é apenas a ferramenta para o fracasso. As partidas de jogos assim acabam se encerrando por desistência de um dos lados e isso é frustrante para os mais investidos no jogo.

------------------------------------------------------------------

author: {'steamid': '76561198025301664', 'num_games_owned': 665, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 394, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 368, 'last_played': 1510454844}
review:
Under the lights of moon and gas, skulking in shadows and pilfering unattended coffers, are the downtrodden and forgotten. These Dickensian societal wastes don't let an oppressive government and cruel police force get them down, because at night - they rule. Criminal enterprises scour the street for gold and victory, taking back what's theirs and what wasn't (but is now). Men, women, and even children smirk slyly while moving stealthily to dip their fingers into pockets or their daggers into backs.

In Antihero, you play as a variety of cutthroat criminals who are tired of being told to live a poor life just because of where, and to whom, they were born. Trying to live an "honest" life is more criminal than actually stealing, so they've taken the lesser of two evils and opt to be creatures of the night. You'll build up your gangs and enlist urchins to rough up rival crooks and take over businesses, siphoning off resources to keep the cycle going. Either through murderous skullduggery or stealthy thievery, you'll be able to claim the title of Master Criminal while taking out your competition. Blackmail, bounties, and boat-loads of booty await you on the cobblestone streets in Antihero!

[h1]To read the full review, click [url=https://www.keengamer.com/article/16766_antihero-review]here[/url]![/h1]

PROS
+ Charming art and fitting music.
+ Simple to learn, difficult to master.
+ Satisfying variety in ways to play and win.

CONS
- Disappointingly short campaign.
